note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)

note.p: Pierre Soule Layton was a Confederate officer and chief of ordnance of the Mississippi State Militia.

Born on January 18, 1839, in Charleston, South Carolina, Layton graduated from the South Carolina State Military Academy. Shortly afterwards he moved to Mississippi and became superintendent of the Brandon State Military Institute. He served as captain in a Mississippi militia artillery unit from Brandon. When the Civil War broke out in 1861, Layton volunteered for military service and was appointed chief of ordnance for the Mississippi State Militia.

In the fall of 1861, he was elected lieutenant colonel of the Fourth Mississippi Infantry Regiment, which entered Confederate service and marched to Tennessee. The regiment participated in the Battle of Fort Donelson, and was captured by Ulysses S. Grant’s troops who surrounded the fort in February 1862. Layton and the other members of the regiment were held as prisoners of war until exchanged by Union and Confederate officials that fall. The Fourth Mississippi Infantry reassembled in Ponchatoula, Louisiana, in October 1862. The original commander resigned his commission and Layton was elected colonel and placed in command. Layton and the regiment participated in the Vicksburg Campaign, and was again captured by soldiers under Grant, in July 1863. After being exchanged this second time, the soldiers of the Fourth Mississippi Infantry joined Braxton Bragg’s army at Chattanooga. Layton departed the regiment by the time it participated in the Atlanta Campaign in 1864.

After the war Layton settled in Meridian, Mississippi. He held a variety of jobs, including an insurance agent, writer and editor of a newspaper, cartographer and civil engineer, and chief engineer of the Waynesboro, Pascagoula and Gulf Coast Railroad.

On November 5, 1878, Layton became involved in a deadly dispute with the sheriff of Lauderdale County, Robert Henderson. On a street in Meridian, Mississippi, Layton and Henderson engaged in a gun battle. Henderson was shot twice in the legs, and Layton was immediately arrested. He was subsequently convicted of assault with intent to kill. He was sentenced to seven years in the state’s penitentiary. However, he was acquitted after an appeal in 1879.

Layton moved to Andalusia, Alabama, late in life and died there on April 2, 1906. His death was likely a suicide, as witnesses said he consumed a large amount of alcohol and then an ounce of laudanum (an opiate). One report noted that he apparently was experiencing family problems. Layton had been married three times, the first of which apparently ended in divorce. He had at least five children who survived to adulthood. Layton is buried in Mount Zion Cemetery in Wayne County, Mississippi.

(Semi-Weekly Mississippian, Jackson, MS, July 4, 1860, October 26, 1860, October 9, 1861; The Clarion-Leger, Jackson, MS, August 8, 1872, and November 6, 1878; The Mississippi Press, Pascagoula, MS, April 4, 1879; The Brookhaven Ledger, Brookhaven, MS, October 9, 1879; The Mississippi Press, Pascagoula, MS, October 5, 1888; Wikipedia; FindaGrave)

Lafayette Haughton was a Confederate officer and later a chancellor of Mississippi’s First District.

Born in Alabama on July 29, 1827, Haughton moved to Mississippi and became a practicing attorney. He married Sarah Priscilla Brownrigg from Columbus, Mississippi, in 1857 and the couple had three children that survived to adulthood. During the Civil War, Haughton served in the Mississippi Militia and the Confederate army, attaining the rank of colonel by the end of the war. After the Civil War, he resumed his law practice, and in 1876 was appointed chancellor of the First Chancery District.
On July 10, 1883, Haughton died at his home in Aberdeen, Mississippi, from injuries he sustained from a fall from a carriage. He was 55 years old. Haughton is buried in Aberdeen, Mississippi.
(FindaGrave; Confederate Veteran, March 1902, No. 3, p. 101; The Aberdeen Examiner, Aberdeen, MS, July 12, 1883)

div.fw: Letter from Quartermaster General Madison McAffee to Army of Mississippi Military Board; November 9, 1861
div.p:
His Excellency
John J. Pettus Govr &c
I hav recieved this morning your special order No 183—to deliver guns to Lt Col Layton which shall receive proper attention.

I regret to say that the number of guns ready for use is very limited, altho, there is quick a large number in prossess. They will be delivered as rapidly as completed in compliance with the above order
